title: How to Help a Man with Intimacy Issues

steps.title: Intimacy issues describe when someone's fear of closeness gets in the way of their ability to form relationships.
steps.content: Intimacy issues describe when someone's fear of closeness gets in the way of their ability to form relationships. Fear of intimacy can impact overall relationship satisfaction and lower sexual desire. Emotionally, a man with intimacy issues might have trouble expressing himself or letting you see his vulnerable side. Physically, a man with intimacy issues might not want to initiate sex and might struggle with being affectionate. [1] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source He might seem "cold" or "distant" at times. He might have low self-esteem or think he doesn't deserve to be with you. He might even express that long-term relationships don’t work for him.

steps.title: Intimacy issues are often caused by underlying anxiety.
steps.content: Intimacy issues are often caused by underlying anxiety. [2] X Expert Source Donna Novak, Psy.D Licensed Clinical Psychologist Expert Interview. 8 December 2020. A man's fear of intimacy can often stem from his concerns about rejection or abandonment—which might go all the way back to his childhood. [3] X Research source In adult life, intimacy issues can come from a string of bad relationships and an avoidant attachment style, which means he'll pull away the closer you try to get. [4] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source He might say he just can’t trust anyone. He may even claim something like, “Relationships are smothering.” He’ll take a long time to warm up to you. He may also look for ways you’ll let him down. Some intimacy issues might also stem from harmful beliefs that men can't be emotional. [5] X Expert Source Josh Spurlock, MA, LPC, CST Licensed Professional Counselor Expert Interview. 13 January 2022.

steps.title: He won’t communicate.
steps.content: He won’t communicate. If you ask him what’s wrong, he’ll deny that anything bothers him. He might even say you read into everything too much. You'll help him relax if you bring up just one important topic at a time. [6] X Research source He has less experience with talking about his emotions, so model how to do this. He shuts down or talks about different topics. Request to stay on the same subject. He’ll distrust anyone who asks too many sensitive questions. Start off slowly.

steps.title: He’s angry all the time.
steps.content: He’s angry all the time. If he loses his temper over small things, like when someone cuts in line, then there’s probably a bigger issue he won’t talk about. If you ask him what he’s really bothered by, he won’t give you an answer or he’ll claim that he’s just irritated by some minor event. He’ll feel more reassured if you tell him it’s natural to be stressed sometimes. [7] X Research source He might raise his voice a lot or have sudden meltdowns. Use a calm tone with him. He may pick fights with you or other people. Try some conflict management skills . He’ll probably be annoyed if you ask him to unpack his reaction. Just give him some space. Reader Poll: We asked 2225 wikiHow readers about the most common signs that man is stressed, and only 6% of them said if he self-medicates with food or alcohol . [Take Poll] So, getting angry or snappy might be a better indication that he’s stressed.

steps.title: He’s a perfectionist.
steps.content: He’s a perfectionist. If he has high standards that he holds himself and others to, he’s probably afraid to talk about flaws. He’ll reject people he's dating and say they’re not good enough for him. He’ll even feel shame for his high standards, but you can remind him that they’re just a part of him and he deserves love, too. [8] X Research source He may also analyze everything he says. Tell him it’s okay to make mistakes. He might work out at the gym for hours. Remind him you embrace more than just his body. He'll tend to criticize others and say something like, “No one ever satisfies all my needs.” Reassure him that it’ll just take time to get to know someone.

steps.title: He’s always distracted.
steps.content: He’s always distracted. If his attention is glued to the phone, video games, or work, he might just want to shut out any serious discussions. Since a deep connection requires people to be present for each other, he’ll find every way to avoid looking at or listening to you. You can continue to be mindful and give him all your focus when you’re able to. [9] X Research source He might also go out all the time. Ask if you can spend a day with him. He may also rush any quality time you have with each other. Request that he slow down and talk to you. He might also give you one-word answers or just nod when you speak. You can match his communication style, but remain sensitive. For instance, you can say, “I understand. That makes total sense.”

steps.title: Build emotional intimacy to deepen your relationship.
steps.content: Build emotional intimacy to deepen your relationship. Whether or not you’ve been able to be physically intimate with him, check in with him regularly. Ask him what’s on his mind and how you can support him. [10] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source When you discuss both his own life and your relationship together, he’ll be invested in a future with you. [11] X Research source Ask about any stress in his life. He’ll like that he can be honest, even when life is challenging. [12] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Do a kind favor for him. You can help with chores or buy tickets to an event he’ll love. He’ll realize how much you care. [13] X Research source Share warm memories with him. When you’re nostalgic, he’ll cherish the relationship you two built. [14] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Talk about the relationship he wants. If he can voice his needs, he’ll feel your dynamic is sustainable. [15] X Expert Source Donna Novak, Psy.D Licensed Clinical Psychologist Expert Interview. 8 December 2020.

steps.title: Work on long-term "experiential" intimacy so he’ll feel secure.
steps.content: Work on long-term "experiential" intimacy so he’ll feel secure. “Experiential” intimacy happens when you two share fun activities with each other. [16] X Expert Source Donna Novak, Psy.D Licensed Clinical Psychologist Expert Interview. 8 December 2020. When you’re both excited about the lives you’ll create together, any worries he has about sex or emotional closeness can fade away. [17] X Research source Work out with him. He’ll feel motivated and have a relationship routine to look forward to. Cook a meal together. You’ll create teamwork in the kitchen and enjoy the creativity. [18] X Research source Bring him on a trip. You can plan the vacation together, then learn how you’ll explore new places as a couple. [19] X Research source Work toward both of your individual goals. He’ll see there’s plenty of room for independence in a relationship. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Show affection in order to connect in ways other than sex.
steps.content: Show affection in order to connect in ways other than sex. Comfort and entertain him outside of the bedroom, tell him you appreciate him, and use caring forms of touch. He’ll learn new strategies to bond with you, and you’ll both build rapport with your clothes on. Cuddle and kiss him. Your quick touches can relieve a lot of his stress. Express gratitude. For example, you can say, “I love that you’re so witty and make me laugh.” Treat him to quality time. You can set aside a couple hours in the evening for each other. [21] X Research source Enjoy activities with him. For example, you can work or go to a trivia night. [22] X Research source Start deep conversations with him. [23] X Expert Source Donna Novak, Psy.D Licensed Clinical Psychologist Expert Interview. 8 December 2020. For instance, you can ask, “What’s the biggest risk you’d take in life?” [24] X Trustworthy Source Greater Good in Action An initiative by UC Berkeley's Greater Good Science Center promoting science-based practices for a meaningful life Go to source

steps.title: Use physical intimacy to create a sense of trust.
steps.content: Use physical intimacy to create a sense of trust. Before you initiate any sex, focus on the sweet moments that lead up to it. See how your chemistry develops, then try to schedule intimacy with him. You’ll be present for each other even with busy lives. Ask him about his fantasies and try out any scenarios you’re comfortable with. Hold him after you’ve reconnected. He’ll be able to let his walls down and cozy up to you. [25] X Research source Plan a romantic date for him. He’ll appreciate all the effort you put in for him. [26] X Research source Listen to emotional music and caress him. You’ll take the pressure off of him to have sex. [27] X Research source Share vulnerabilities with him. When you both talk about any fears or anxieties, you’ll be each other’s confidantes and can solve problems together. [28] X Research source
